sen.j: 鬼（おに）は、日本の妖怪。
sen.e: Oni is a Japanese specter.
Oni is a Japanese specter.
Oni is a Japanese specter.

sen.j: 民話や郷土信仰に登場する悪い物、恐ろしい物、強い物を象徴する存在。
sen.e: It's a symbol of a bad, scary or strong thing in folk tales and local religions.
In folk tales and local religions it symbolizes something bad, frightening or strong.
In folk tales and local religions it symbolizes something bad, frightening or strong.

sen.j: そこから鬼という言葉には「強い」「悪い」という意味もある。
sen.e: Accordingly, a word Oni means "strong" and "bad."
Accordingly, the word Oni means "strong" and "bad."
Accordingly, the word Oni means 'strong' and 'bad.'

sen.j: （鬼 (曖昧さ回避)でも説明。）
sen.e: (Explained also in Oni (disambiguation))
(Explained also in Oni (disambiguation))
(Explained also in Oni (disambiguation))

tit.e: Oni in Premodern and Modern Times
Oni in Premodern and Modern Times
Oni in Premodern and Modern Times

sen.j: 現代の日本人が、「鬼」と言われて一般的に連想する姿は、頭に角と巻き毛の頭髪を具え、口に牙を有し、指に鋭い爪が生え、虎の毛皮の褌を腰に纏い、表面に突起のある金棒を持った大男である。
sen.e: The image that the modern Japanese generally associate with "Oni" is a big man with horns and curly hair on the head, fangs in the mouth, sharp claws on the fingers, wearing tiger skin Fundoshi around the hips and carrying an iron bat with spinous surface.

The image that the modern Japanese generally associate with "Oni" is a big man with horns and curly hair on the head, fangs in the mouth, sharp claws on the fingers, wearing a tiger-skin Fundoshi around the hips and carrying an iron bat with a spiny surface.

The image that the modern Japanese generally associate with 'Oni' is a big man with horns and curly hair on the head and fangs in the mouth, sharp claws on the fingers, wearing a tiger-skin Fundoshi around the hips and carrying an iron bat with a spiny surface.

sen.j: これは、丑の方と寅の方の間の方角（艮うしとら）を鬼門と呼ぶことによるもので、牛の角と体、虎の牙と爪を持ち、虎の皮を身に付けているとされた。
sen.e: This stems from the fact that the direction between Ushi (ox) and Tora (tiger), which is northeast (Ushitora), is called Kimon (ogre gate), and an oni was supposed to have horns and a body of an ox, have fangs and claws of a tiger and wear tiger skin.

This stems from the fact that the direction between Ushi (ox) and Tora (tiger), which is northeast (Ushitora), is called Kimon (ogre gate), and an oni was supposed to have the horns and body of an ox, have the fangs and claws of a tiger and wear a tiger skin.

This stems from the fact that the direction between Ushi (ox) and Tora (tiger), which is northeast (Ushitora), is called Kimon (ogre gate), and an oni was supposed to have the horns and body of an ox, have the fangs and claws of a tiger and wear a tiger skin.

sen.j: この姿は平安時代に確立したものである。
sen.e: This image was established in the Heian era.
This image was established during the Heian period.
This image was established during the Heian period.

sen.j: 余談だが、丑寅の方角を鬼門とする時、その対にあたる方角、猿（申）.雉（酉）．犬（戌）に守護の役を与え、鬼退治に向かう桃太郎もある種の意味を持つと推測できる。
sen.e: As an aside, when the direction of Ushitora is assigned to Kimon, the counter directions, monkey (Saru), pheasant (Tori) and dog (Inu) are assigned as guards, which travelled to kill Oni in the story of Momotaro, and it seems to have some kind of meaning.

As an aside, when the direction of Ushitora is assigned to Kimon, the counter directions, monkey (Saru), pheasant (Tori) and dog (Inu) are assigned as guards, which traveled to kill Oni in the story of Momotaro, and it seems to have some kind of meaning.

Incidentally, when the direction of Ushitora is assigned to Kimon, the counter directions of monkey (Saru), pheasant (Tori) and dog (Inu) are assigned as guards, which sought to kill Oni in the story of Momotaro (Peach Boy), it seems to have some kind of meaning.

sen.j: 酒呑童子は赤毛で角があり、髭も髪も眉毛もつながっており、手足は熊の手のようであるとされている。
sen.e: Shuten-Doji is supposed to have red hair and horns, with his beard, hair and eyebrows all connected, and to have hands and feet like a bear's paws.
Shuten-Doji is supposed to have red hair and horns, with his beard, hair and eyebrows all connected, and to have hands and feet like the paws of a bear.
Shuten-Doji is supposed to have red hair and horns, with his beard, hair and eyebrows all connected, and to have hands and feet like the paws of a bear.

sen.j: 鬼は元々はこのような定まった姿は持っておらず、後述する語源の「おぬ（隠）」の通り姿の見えないこともあった。
sen.e: Oni didn't originally have such specific figure, and it was sometimes invisible as its origin word "Onu" described below.
Oni didn't originally have such a specific figure, and it was sometimes invisible as per its origin word "Onu" described below.
Oni didn't originally have such a specific figure, and it was sometimes invisible as per its origin word 'Onu,' as described below.

sen.j: まれには、見目麗しい異性の姿で現れて若い男や女を誘うことがある。
sen.e: On rare occasions, it appears as a beautiful person of the opposite sex and seduce young men and women.
On rare occasions it appears as a beautiful person of the opposite sex and can seduce young men and women.
On rare occasions it appears as a beautiful person of the opposite sex and can seduce young men and women.

sen.j: 現在の鬼の姿は仏教の羅刹が混入したものである。
sen.e: The present image of Oni is mixed with Rasetsu of Buddhism.
The present image of Oni is mixed with Rasetsu, of Buddhism.
The present image of Oni is mixed with Rasetsu, of Buddhism.

sen.j: 民話に登場する鬼は、金または栗色の髪で赤い肌である事が多い為、ロシア方面などからの海賊を、外国人を知らない民衆が見て怪物だと思い込んだのではないかとも言われている（色素の少ない肌は日焼けすると赤くなる）。
sen.e: Since Oni appears in folk tales with gold or light brown hair and red skin in most cases, it is said that Japanese people who had never seen foreigners took pirates from Russia or other countries for monsters (lightly-pigmented skin turns red after sunburn).

Because Oni appears in folk tales most often with gold or light brown hair and red skin, it is said that Japanese people who had never seen foreigners mistook pirates from Russia or other countries for monsters (as lightly pigmented skin turns red due to sunburn).

Because Oni appears in folk tales most often with gold or light brown hair and red skin, it is said that Japanese people who had never seen foreigners mistook pirates from Russia or other countries for monsters (as lightly pigmented skin turns red due to sunburn).

sen.j: 「おに」の語はおぬ（隠）が転じたもので、元来は姿の見えないもの、この世ならざるものであることを意味した。
sen.e: The word "Oni" derives from Onu, which originally meant invisibility and unworldly things.
The word "Oni" derives from Onu, which originally meant invisibility and unworldly things.
The word 'Oni' derives from Onu, which originally meant invisibility and unworldly things.

sen.j: そこから人の力を超えたものの意となり、後に、人に災いをもたらす伝説上のヒューマノイドのイメージが定着した。
sen.e: By extension, it meant things transcending people's power, and then, the image of a humanoid in legend bringing harm to people has been well established.
By extension, it meant things that transcend human power, whereupon the image of a humanoid in legend, bringing harm to people, became well established.
By extension, it meant things transcending people's power; subsequently, the image of a humanoid bringing harm to people became well established in legend.

sen.j: さらに、陰陽思想や浄土思想と習合し、地獄における閻魔配下の獄卒であるとされた。
sen.e: Furthermore, it is integrated with Yin-Yan philosophy and Pure Land philosophy, and it has been regarded as Gokusotsu ogre working under Enma ogre in the hell.
Furthermore, it is integrated with the Yin-Yan and Pure Land philosophies, and it has been regarded as the Gokusotsu ogre working under the ogre Emma in hell.
Furthermore, it is integrated with the Yin-Yan and Pure Land philosophies, and it has been regarded as the Gokusotsu ogre working under the ogre Enma in hell.

tit.j: 説話文学に見られる鬼
tit.e: Oni in the Literature of Legend
Oni in the Literature of Legend

sen.j: 百鬼夜行とは、平安時代に都の中を歩いてゆくとされた化け物行列のことである。
sen.e: Hyakkiyako is a monster parade which was said to march in the capital in the Heian era.
Hyakkiyako is a monster parade that has been said to march through the capital during the Heian period.
Hyakkiyako is a monster parade that has been said to march through the capital during the Heian period.

sen.j: 『宇治拾遺物語』巻一の十七で修行僧が龍泉寺という寺で、百鬼夜行に遭った話が伝わっている。
sen.e: "Tales from the Uji Collection" introduces a story that a ascetic monk met Hyakkiyako at Ryusen-ji Temple in the chapter 17 in the volume 1.
sen.cmt: 宇治拾遺物語http://eow.alc.co.jp/宇治拾遺/UTF-8/
sen.e: "Tales from the Uji Collection" introduces a story in which an ascetic monk met Hyakkiyako at Ryusen-ji Temple in Chapter 17 of Volume 1.
"Uji-shui monogatari (Tales from the Uji Collection)" introduces a story in which an ascetic monk met Hyakkiyako at Ryusen-ji Temple in Chapter 17 of Volume 1.

sen.j: また、『今昔物語集』にも巻第十四に若者が百鬼夜行に遭ったという話が伝わっている。
sen.e: "Tales of Times Now Past" also introduces a story that a young man met Hyakkiyako in the volume 14.
"Tales of Times Now Past," in Volume 14, also introduces a story that a young man met Hyakkiyako.
"Konjaku monogatarishu (Tales of Times Now Past)," in Volume 14, also introduces a story that a young man met Hyakkiyako.

sen.j: 当時、百鬼夜行を目撃すると死んだり病気になるなどと恐れられていたが、この二つの話はどちらも信仰が身を助けたという話になっている。
sen.e: At that time, people were afraid that seeing Hyakkiyako would make them die or become sick, but these two are stories that faith saved them.
At that time, people were afraid that seeing Hyakkiyako would make them die or become sick, but these two are stories that faith saved them.
At the time, people were afraid that they would die or become sick if they saw a Hyakkiyako, but in both of these stories faith saved the protagonists.
sen.cmt: these two---them.は日本語の意味合いを訳しました。

sen.j: 『宇治拾遺物語』巻一には、瘤取り爺の説話が所収されているが、爺が目撃した鬼として、赤い者や目が一つの者、口がない者など様々な異形な者がいたとされている。
sen.e: The volume 1 of "Tales from the Uji Collection" has a folklore of the Old Man with a Wen, and the old man saw various Oni, who are odd-looking such as a red one, one with an eye, or one without a mouth.
Volume 1 of "Tales from the Uji Collection" has a folklore of the Old Man with a Wen, and the old man saw various Oni, who are odd-looking, such as a red one, one with an eye, or one without a mouth.
Volume 1 of "Uji-shui monogatari" has a folklore of the Old Man with a Wen, and the old man saw various Oni, who are odd-looking, such as a red one, one with an eye or one without a mouth.

tit.e: The Four Ogres of Chikata FUJIWARA
The Four Ogres of Chikata Fujiwara
The Four Ogres of Chikata FUJIWARA
tit.cmt: 苗字を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 藤原千方に使役されたと言われる四人の鬼。
sen.e: They are four Ogres which are said to have worked for Chikata FUJIWARA.
They are four Ogres which are said to have worked for Chikata Fujiwara.
They are four ogres which are said to have worked for Chikata FUJIWARA.

sen.j: 『今昔物語集』に登場する女性の鬼しか存在しない島。
sen.e: It's an island where only female Oni live described in "Tales of Times Now Past."
This is an island where only female Oni live, as described in "Tales of Times Now Past."
This is an island where only female Oni live, as described in "Konjaku monogatarishu."

sen.j: 後に日本の南方あるいは東方に存在すると信じられるようになった。
sen.e: Later, it was believed to lie to the south or the east of Japan.
Later, it was believed to lie to the south or the east of Japan.
Later, it was believed to lie to the south or the east of Japan.

sen.j: 羅刹国を参照のこと。
sen.e: See Rasetsu-koku.
See "Rasetsu-koku."
See "Rasetsu-koku."

sen.j: 生前に貪欲であった者は、死後に餓鬼道におち、餓鬼となるとされている。
sen.e: A man who was greedy during his life is supposed to fall into the preta world and become a preta.
A man who was greedy during his life is supposed to have fallen into the preta world and become a preta.
A man who was greedy during his life is supposed to have fallen into the preta world and become a preta.

sen.j: また、地獄で閻魔の配下として、鬼が獄卒の役を務めているとされる。
sen.e: And Oni is supposed to play a role of Gokusotsu ogre working for Enma ogre in the hell.
Oni is supposed to play a role of Gokusotsu ogre working for Enma ogre in hell.
Oni is supposed to play a role of Gokusotsu ogre working for Enma ogre in hell.

sen.j: 人に化けて、人を襲う鬼の話が伝わる一方で、憎しみや嫉妬の念が満ちて人が鬼に変化したとする話もある。
sen.e: While stories that Oni takes the form of a human and attacks people goes the round, there are also stories that full of hatred and jealousy makes human change into Oni.
While stories that Oni takes the form of a human and attacks people go around, there are also stories that being full of hatred and jealousy will make a human change into Oni.
While stories that Oni takes the form of a human and attacks people go around, there are also stories that being full of hatred and jealousy will make a human change into Oni.

sen.j: 代表的な例としては、能の「鉄輪」や「紅葉狩 (能)」に、嫉妬心から鬼と化した女性の話が伝わっている。
sen.e: As major examples, stories that a woman who changed into Oni out of jealousy are introduced in "Kanawa" and "Momijigari (Noh)" in Noh.
As major examples, stories that a woman who changed into Oni out of jealousy are introduced in "Kanawa" and "Momijigari (Noh)" in Noh.

sen.e: Oe-cho, Kyoto Prefecture at the foot of the mountain (current Fukuchiyama City) is famous for promotion of "Oni's home."

The Kizumi and Sasuto mountains are the site of Japan's oldest Oni legend, which was handed down in Hoki Town, Tottori Prefecture.

sen.e: Akumikambe-shinmeisha, a Shinmei-jinja Shrine in Toyohashi City, Aichi Prefecture.

sen.j: 天下の奇祭と呼ばれる国指定重要無形民俗文化財の鬼祭が行われる。
sen.e: A well-known strange festival, Oni Festival as officially-designated significant intangible folk cultural asset is held.
A well-known strange festival, the Oni Festival--an officially designated significant intangible folk cultural asset--is held.
A well-known strange festival, the Oni Festival--an officially designated significant intangible folk cultural asset--is held.

sen.j: この他、日本全国に形を変えて鬼の伝承が伝わっている。
sen.e: Besides these, myths of Oni are handed down in different forms all over Japan.
Additionally, other Oni myths have been handed down in various forms throughout Japan.
Additionally, other Oni myths have been handed down in various forms throughout Japan.

sen.j: 中国で鬼（グウェイ）という場合、死霊、死者の霊魂中国の宗教（道教など）のことを指す。
sen.e: In China, Oni (Guei) indicates a ghost, the spirit of a dead person and Chinese religion (Taoism).
sen.cmt: 原文「中国の宗教（道教など）」はWikiページにはなく、文脈もおかしいのですが、そのまま訳しました。
sen.e: In China, Oni (Guei) indicates a ghost, the spirit of a dead person and Chinese religion (Taoism).
In China, Oni (Guei) indicates a ghost, the spirit of a dead person and Chinese religion (Taoism).

sen.j: 日本で言う「亡霊」の方がニュアンスとして近い。
sen.e: It is closer to Japanese "apparition" as its implication.
It is closer to Japanese "apparition" as its implication.
It is closer to the Japanese 'apparition' in terms of its implication.

sen.j: 中国では、直接鬼と呼ぶのはタブーであることから、婉曲して好兄弟ともいう。
sen.e: Since calling Oni directly is a taboo in China, it is also called good brothers euphemistically.
Since calling Oni directly is a taboo in China, it is also euphemistically called "good brothers."
Because in China it is taboo to call upon Oni directly, it is also euphemistically called Good Brothers.

sen.j: また日本にもこの思想が入っており、人が死ぬことを指して「鬼籍に入る」などと言う言い方がある他、元来の意味合いと混交したイメージでも捉えられている。
sen.e: This idea was transmitted to Japan, so death of a person is expressed as "Kiseki ni iru" (Join the ranks of Oni), and the image mixed with the original meaning is also held.
This idea was transmitted to Japan, so the death of a person is expressed as "Kiseki ni iru" (Join the ranks of Oni), and the image mixed with the original meaning is also held.
This idea spread throughout Japan so the death of a person became expressed as 'Kiseki ni iru' (Join the ranks of Oni); this image mixed together with the original meaning has remained.
sen.cmt: 全体的に訳し直しました。

sen.j: 従って、中国語で「鬼－」と言う表現は、必ずしも勇猛等を意味しない。
sen.e: Therefore, expressions with "Oni-" in Chinese doesn't necessarily mean bravery.
Therefore, expressions with "Oni-" in Chinese doesn't necessarily mean bravery.
Therefore, expressions with 'Oni-' in Chinese don't necessarily imply bravery.

sen.j: 戦前の日本軍で、ある将官が「鬼将軍」と渾名され、当人は軍人として誇りにしていたが、実はその痩せた風貌を揶揄したものであったというエピソードがこれを物語る。
sen.e: In the Japan Army before the war, a general was called "Oni shogun" and he was proud of it as a military man, but in fact, it was to make fun of his thin appearance, which explains this.
In the Japan Army before the war, a general was called "Oni shogun" and he was proud of it as a military man; but in fact it was to make fun of his thin appearance, which explains this.
In the Japan Army before the war, a particular general was called 'Oni shogun' and he was proud of it as a military man; but in fact it was to make fun of his thin appearance, which explains this.

sen.j: 文禄・慶長の役の際、島津義弘の率いる軍勢を明軍は「鬼石曼子」と言って恐れたとの逸話においても「鬼」はその勇猛さよりも、つまらない奴や忌々しい奴という蔑視表現に使われる。
sen.e: At Bunroku Keicho no eki War, it is said that the army led by Yoshihiro SHIMAZU was called "Oni Shimazu" and feared by the Ming army, but this "Oni" is used as an contempt expression for a worthless man or a disgusting man rather than as bravery.

Regarding the Bunroku Keicho no eki War, it is said that the army led by Yoshihiro Shimazu was called "Oni Shimazu" and was feared by the Ming army, but this "Oni" is used as an expression of contempt for a worthless man or a disgusting man rather than as bravery.

Regarding the Bunroku Keicho no eki War, it is said that the army led by Yoshihiro SHIMAZU was called 'Oni Shimazu' and was feared by the Ming army, but this 'Oni' is used as an expression of contempt for a worthless or disgusting man instead of implying bravery.

sen.j: 拝外意識により、欧米人を「洋鬼」と呼び、それに遅れて進出した日本人を「東洋鬼」と呼ぶのもこの類である。
sen.e: From their xenophobia, they call Westerners "Western Oni" and the Japanese who advanced later "Orient Oni," which is on the same basis.
From their xenophobia, they call Westerners "Western Oni" and the Japanese who advanced later "Orient Oni," which is on the same basis.
From their xenophobia, they call Westerners 'Western Oni,' and for the same reason the Japanese who subsequently advanced are called 'Orient Oni.'

sen.j: また、かつて中国民衆が日本の総理大臣を「小泉小鬼」と呼ぶことがあったが、日本の総理を恐れるのではなく小馬鹿にする表現であった。
sen.e: Once, the Chinese public called Japanese Prime Minister "Koizumi Ko-oni," which doesn't mean they were afraid of him, but they made fun of him.
Once, the Chinese public called Japanese Prime Minister "Koizumi Ko-oni," which doesn't mean they were afraid of him but that they were making fun of him.
Once, the Chinese public called Japanese Prime Minister 'Koizumi Ko-oni (Koizumi, Little Demon),' which doesn't mean they were afraid of him but that they were making fun of him.

sen.j: 鬼から派生した用語
sen.e: Terms Derived From Oni
Terms Derived From Oni
Terms Derived From Oni

sen.j: 現象 鬼火
sen.e: Phenomenon: Onibi
Phenomenon: Onibi

Place name: Oni-oshidashi, Onigashima, Onigajo, Onigajoyama, Oni-mura

sen.j: 生物 オニヤンマ
sen.e: Creature: Oni-yanma
Creature: Oni-yanma
Creature: Oni-yanma (largest kind of dragonfly in Japan)
sen.cmt: オニヤンマの説明として(largest kind of dragonfly in Japan)としました。

sen.j: その他 多数
sen.e: Others: numerous
Others: various
Others: various

sen.j: 童話などにも数多く登場し、多くは主人公に倒される。
sen.e: Oni are appeared in fairy tales many times, and they are in most cases defeated by the main character.
Oni are frequently depicted in fairy tales, and in most cases they are defeated by the main character.
Oni are frequently depicted in fairy tales, and in most cases they are defeated by the main character.

sen.j: 代表的な例としては、一寸法師、桃太郎などがあげられる。
sen.e: Issun Boshi and Momotaro are the major examples.
Issun Boshi and Momotaro are the major examples.
Issun Boshi (One-Inch Boy) and Momotaro are the major examples.

sen.j: この鬼退治のモチーフは、古くから見られ、渡辺綱は酒呑童子など多くの鬼を退治したとされている。
sen.e: The motif of Oni extermination has been seen since old times, and WATANABE no Tsuna is said to have exterminated lots of Oni including Shuten-Doji.
The motif of Oni extermination has been seen since old times, and Watanabe no Tsuna is said to have exterminated lots of Oni, including Shuten-Doji.
The motif of Oni extermination has been seen since old times, and WATANABE no Tsuna is said to have exterminated lots of Oni, including Shuten-Doji.
sen.cmt: 苗字を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 近世になると、『泣いた赤鬼』（浜田廣介）や『おにたのぼうし』（あまんきみこ）など、鬼はただ悪いだけではなく、悪いとされているけれども優しい心を持つ者もいるという童話が見られるようになる。
sen.e: In early modern days, some fairy tales including "Red Ogre's Tears" (Hirosuke HAMADA) and "Onita's Hat" (Kimiko AMAN) have shown there are some of Oni, supposed to be bad, still with a tender heart, besides bad Oni.
sen.cmt: 泣いた赤鬼、おにたのぼうしhttp://www.scils.rutgers.edu/professional-development/childlit/Culture/oni.html
sen.e: In early modern days, some fairy tales including "Red Ogre's Tears" (Hirosuke Hamada) and "Onita's Hat" (Kimiko Aman) have shown there are some of Oni, supposed to be bad, still with a tender heart, besides bad Oni.

In the early modern period, some fairy tales including "Naita Akaoni (Red Ogre's Tears)" (Hirosuke HAMADA) and "Onita-no-boshi (Onita's Hat)" (Kimiko AMAN) have indicated that there are some Oni, supposedly bad but still with tenderness of heart, besides the bad Oni.
sen.cmt: 苗字を大文字にしました。原題を追加しました。

sen.j: あるいは非情・非論理的な暴力の象徴として、あるいは虐げられた異形の存在として、永井豪は鬼を作品の中心的存在として取り上げてきた。
sen.e: Go NAGAI has featured Oni for a key player of his works, as a symbol of cruel and illogical violence at times, and as an oppressed heteromorphic being at other times.

sen.j: ジェスチャー
sen.e: Gesture
Gesture
Gesture

sen.j: 基本的に鬼は怖いものであり、また鬼の顔も怒った表情である事が多い為、誰か（第三者）が怒っているという事や、機嫌が悪いという事などを示す手段として、両手の人差し指を立てて、鬼の角に見立てて頭の上に掲げるジェスチャーが存在し、話し相手に（当人に気づかれない様に）その人とのトラブルに巻き込まれない様に、注意を促す目的で使用される事が多い。
sen.e: Since Oni is basically a scary thing and Oni mostly has an angry face, as means of expressing somebody (the third person) is angry or has a bad mood, there exists a gesture to put both index fingers over the head resembling the horns of Oni, for the purpose of giving a warning to others (without being noticed by the person in question) not to get in trouble with the person.

Because Oni is basically a scary thing and Oni mostly has an angry face, as a means of expressing someone (the third person) who is angry or is in a bad mood, there exists a gesture to put both index fingers over the head resembling the horns of Oni, for the purpose of giving a warning to others (without being noticed by the person in question) so as not to get in trouble with that person.

Because Oni is basically a scary thing and Oni mostly has an angry face, as a means of expressing someone (the third person) who is angry or is in a bad mood, there exists a gesture to put both index fingers over the head resembling the horns of Oni, for the purpose of giving a warning to others (without being noticed by the person in question) so as not to get in trouble with that person.
